title: 106_s845
content: Liability of business entities providing facilities to nonprofit organizations. Definitions for terms related to liability of business entities providing facilities to nonprofit organizations are provided. These include definitions for business entity, facility, gross negligence, intentional misconduct, and nonprofit organization. The term "nonprofit organization" refers to organizations exempt from tax under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code or those organized for charitable, civic, educational, religious, welfare, or health purposes. The term "State" includes all states, territories, and political subdivisions of the United States. Business entities are not liable for injuries or deaths at their facilities when used by nonprofit organizations outside of the business scope, authorized by the entity. This limitation applies to civil liability under Federal and State law. Nonprofit organizations can use business facilities without liability for injuries or deaths, regardless of payment. However, this exception does not apply in cases of gross negligence, intentional misconduct, hate crimes, sexual offenses, or acts of violence or terrorism. The Act preempts state laws inconsistent with it, except for those providing additional liability protection. It does not supersede federal or state health and safety laws. States can choose not to apply the Act. The Act preempts state laws inconsistent with it, except for those providing additional liability protection. States can choose not to apply the Act if they pass a statute declaring so for civil actions involving only state citizens.
